name: Hakata Ramen
instructions: Prepare or reheat a batch of tonkotsu broth until it reaches a simmer.
In a separate pot, boil the thin ramen noodles according to the package instructions, then drain thoroughly.
Divide the cooked noodles into serving bowls.
Pour the hot tonkotsu broth over the noodles in each bowl.
Top each bowl with a slice of chashu pork, a spoonful of pickled ginger, a sprinkle of sesame seeds, and chopped green onions.
Optionally, serve with additional noodles on the side for kaedama (noodle refill).

name: Hiyashi Chūka
ingredients: 1 egg, scrambled and cut into strips
instructions: Boil the chilled ramen noodles until just tender, then rinse them under cold water and drain thoroughly to cool.
Julienne the cucumber, cut the ham into thin strips, and cook the egg into a thin omelet, then cut it into strips.
Slice the tomato into wedges or half-moons.
Mix the soy sauce, rice vinegar, and sesame oil together in a bowl to create the dressing.
Arrange the cold noodles on a serving plate or bowl.
Neatly place the cucumber, ham, egg, and tomato on top of the noodles.
Drizzle the dressing over the toppings just before serving.

name: Kitakata Ramen
instructions: In a large pot, combine the pork bone and dried sardines with water and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer for 1 to 1.5 hours.
Strain the broth into a clean pot and stir in the soy sauce to season.
Cook the flat curly noodles according to the package instructions, then divide into serving bowls.
Pour the hot broth over the noodles.
Top each bowl with pork belly slices and a generous amount of chopped green onions.

name: Kyoto Ramen
instructions: Place the chicken carcass and pork bone into a pot filled with water and simmer for about 2 hours to make a rich broth.
Strain the broth and season with soy sauce to taste.
Cook the thick ramen noodles until tender and place them in serving bowls.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles.
Top with chopped green onions, bamboo shoots, and slices of chashu pork.

name: Miso Ramen
instructions: Heat a pot over medium heat and sauté the ground pork until fully browned.
Add the miso paste and stir well to coat the pork evenly.
Pour in the chicken broth and simmer the mixture for 10 to 15 minutes.
In the meantime, cook the ramen noodles according to package instructions and place them in bowls.
Pour the hot miso broth over the noodles.
Top with corn kernels, a pat of butter, and fresh bean sprouts before serving.

name: Onomichi Ramen
instructions: In a pot, simmer the chicken carcass and dried sardines in water for about 2 hours to create a light but flavorful broth.
Strain the broth and stir in soy sauce and minced pork back fat.
Cook the flat ramen noodles and place them into serving bowls.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and top each bowl with a slice of chashu pork and chopped green onions.

name: Shio Ramen
instructions: Combine the chicken stock and seafood stock in a pot and bring to a gentle simmer.
Season with sea salt and stir well.
Cook the ramen noodles separately and divide into serving bowls.
Pour the hot broth over the noodles.
Garnish with chopped green onions, a sheet of nori (cut if needed), and narutomaki slices.

name: Shoyu Ramen
instructions: Heat the chicken stock in a saucepan and add soy sauce to season the broth.
Boil the ramen noodles according to the package instructions and place them in serving bowls.
Pour the seasoned broth over the noodles.
Top with menma, a sheet of nori (cut if necessary), chopped green onions, and a halved soft-boiled egg.

name: Tantanmen
instructions: In a pan over medium heat, cook the ground pork with the minced garlic until the pork is browned and aromatic.
Add sesame paste, soy sauce, and chicken broth. Stir well and let it simmer for about 10 minutes.
Cook the ramen noodles separately and divide them into bowls.
Pour the spicy sesame-infused broth over the noodles.
Top with cooked pork, chopped scallions, and an optional drizzle of extra chili oil for more heat.

name: Tonkotsu Ramen
instructions: Boil the pork bones in a large pot for 8 to 12 hours until the broth becomes rich and creamy white. Add water as needed during simmering.
Strain the broth to remove solids, then season with soy sauce and crushed garlic.
Cook ramen noodles and place them in serving bowls.
Pour the tonkotsu broth over the noodles.
Top with slices of chashu pork, wood ear mushrooms, green onions, and halved soft-boiled egg.

name: Tokyo-style Ramen
instructions: Simmer the chicken carcass and pork bone in water for about 2 hours to extract the flavor and create a light broth.
Strain the broth and season with soy sauce.
Cook the wavy ramen noodles and place them in serving bowls.
Pour the broth over the noodles and garnish with slices of narutomaki, halved soft-boiled egg, and a sheet of nori.

name: Tsukemen
ingredients: 2 cups concentrated pork or chicken broth
instructions: Boil the thick ramen noodles until cooked, then rinse under cold water to cool and remove excess starch.
In a saucepan, warm the concentrated broth and mix in soy sauce and rice vinegar.
Place the noodles on a serving plate and pour the dipping broth into a separate small bowl.
Serve the noodles with slices of chashu and a sheet of nori on the side.
To eat, dip the noodles into the broth before each bite and enjoy with toppings.
